Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 09:31PM Ysa wrote: Hi, everyone. It's nice to meet you! I turned 56 this past September (was diagnosed with the breast tumor a year ago). I have one diagnosed met, in my L1 vertebrae. Taking Letrozole and Xgeva for now (with targeted lumbar radiation this month) until seeing what April scans reveal. Am scheduled to finish (I hope) reconstruction on May 3. I'm married to an amazing guy, with a cat and parakeet who act like spoiled kids (probably my fault...lol). I am a retired social worker who spent some time subsequently as a law firm office manager and now I enjoy home making, gardening, re-learning my cooking skills, a variety of crafting, and focusing on being as healthy as I can be under the circumstances. Have good days and not so good depending upon side effects or back pain...but try to keep moving forward and focusing on the joy and fun to be had (while allowing myself the occasional day hiding under the covers). Despite a few long posts, am actually quite shy so lurk here often and tend not to post a lot, but have developed much affection and appreciation for you wonderful women. Light and hugs to all...

Posts.Content: May 12, 2013 12:43AM Ysa wrote: Back pain is extremely common following DIEP surgery and will eventually get better. Getting up and walking is a great way to help get it back in shape but don't overdo, either. You will likely be a bit stooped when you stand up and that is also normal and will get better. Talk to your Dr about a muscle relaxer if it's too painful, and take your pain meds on schedule so the pain doesn't get ahead of you. Warm, moist heat is also great. Hang in there and take advantage of any help you can find until you start feeling better.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 06:35PM Ysa wrote: I am relatively new, as well, and keep meaning to post a more introductory hello but never seem to get onto my desktop to do so (mostly post with my mini tablet and it's hard to type on it). Since my brief trip from stage Ib to IV last year, I have lurked several times daily, trying to be a supportive sister as I was able. Apple's passing was the first to hit me strongly and I really had to process my feelings about dealing with these losses. However, I have learned so much and grown to appreciate you all so deeply, that I decided I am willing to take the occasional horrible with the daily wonderful (and in that I am referring to both the tears/fears as well as triumphs) that you all share. That this place allows so many lovely people to come and lay open their hearts is a gift beyond belief. Like Msmerz, I often struggle with trying to figure out if I fit in, thus my recent attempts to get over that by reaching out and letting you know another sister is rooting for you. Some days I do better than others but I find myself always drawn back and looking forward to hearing how you are. Thank you all for being there for me, even if you aren't aware how often you are. Hugs and Light.

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 11:05AM Ysa wrote: Thank you all for sharing your experiences and some things that helped.  I'm going to try it all.  As for the cortisone injection, actually my reaction was a whole lot worse than the typical flush.  Everything from the flush to rapid heartbeat, migraine headache that didn't go away for two days (I rarely get those), extreme thirst, irritability and racing thoughts, unable to sleep for two nights, and sweating through clothing for two days (I had to change my nightgown twice the first night).  I get a similar reaction the rare times I have to take prednisone for my asthma so I am pretty sure I'm just really sensitive to steroids.  I've read where other folks have had similar issues so, while it doesn't appear common, neither is it unheard of.  Yay...lol. I've been working on my PT stretching exercises so am hoping that will get me through BMX/recon surgery.  I may try acupuncture on the other side of it, too.  Don't know exactly where I'll stand with having shoulder surgery down the line but it's one thing at a time for now.  Thanks, again, for the suggestions!  Sending hugs to you all.  = )

Posts.Title: A sad update on Suze 35 Suze35 Janie-bug

Posts.Content: Ysa wrote: Received phone call from my radiologist a bit ago (had my core biopsy yesterday afternoon) and was told that they have determined at least that I have IDC, grade 1.  The lump is very small (just under a CM).  It will be a few days before they will know anything on the receptor status.  There is hope that the nodes will be fine since it was caught so early but I guess they will do the sentinel node stuff when surgery happens.  All in all, not the best news but certainly very far from the worst.   As far as the biopsy went, it was pretty easy.  A little bit of tenderness left over when I move around in certain ways (and a spot of bleeding), but worst outcome was big red welts from the adhesive on the strips they used to cover the gauze. I knew when I left that they hoped they might have news as early as today but certainly on Monday and the radiologist told me that they always try to follow patient wishes for notification but typically give results over the phone.  Her biggest worry was whether or not I'd rather have the weekend to regroup or hear on Monday when I could spring into action.  I weighed that carefully for about a second and said call me on Friday if you have them (really, the NOT knowing is the worst for me...). Had barely gotten home from the biopsy when my PCP called and suggested I make an appt. with a breast surgeon (he had the recommendation of who and why all ready for me), even though the pathologist report wasn't going to be ready for a day or two.  So, I did and they were lovely, with the understanding I would call and cancel if it was benign. Shortly after talking to the radiologist today, their patient care advocate called and they are going to call the BS office and try to get me in a little sooner (it's currently scheduled for the 19th) but that might be up in the air depending on their schedule.  She was also terrific, gave more information (like it matters now...NOT...but BIRAD was 5) and even gave me some advice on handling the red welts from the bandage strips.  She also mentioned that the BS would likely want to do an MRI. So, that's it.  Vascillating between numb, tired, and worn out.  Have some anxiety (and PCP gave me his blessing on taking Xanax when I needed it) but am sort of in that phase where now that I know what's really happening, it's actually a little more bearable. Sending Light to all still waiting and surviving.  Courage doesn't always roar. Sometimes, courage is the quiet voice at the end of the day saying "I will try again tomorrow". (Mary Anne Radmacher); one 9 mm and one 7mm mass in right breast, bone mets/lumbar spine, Xgeva started 12/2012 Dx 1/6/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2012 Femara (letrozole) Dx 11/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 2/19/2013 Bone Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 11:11AM Ysa wrote: Thank you so much!  I'm sure you are very well acquainted with the wide range of emotions that swing back and forth--sometimes suddenly and unexpectedly--one gets when newly diagnosed.  Humor is how my family deals with all things crisis-oriented...thank god! Yesterday (the day I got the news) I allowed myself the "I just got diagnosed with bc and can eat a pint of Ben & Jerry's if I want to" indulgence (I've worked really hard to lose weight this past year so icecream isn't on my usual menu).  Thank goodness for a husband who never said a thing other than "can I drive you to the store"...although he did later comment that I was NOT allowed to get a bc diagnosis every time I wanted to eat icecream.   My sister has offered to donate her butt fat if reconstructive surgery is needed (I hated to let her down by telling her that, if reconstruction was needed they were SO taking MY excess belly fat).  Best of all, both my sister and step-sister are calling their docs on Monday to get their (already overdue) yearly mammograms, and my sister (who is 11 younger than I and now has both a mom and a sister who have had bc) is also going to request BRCA gene testing. If anyone needs a shoulder or venting place, please feel free to ask.  I do feel incredibly blessed to have had the diagnostic process be so smooth and speedy (reading some of the other stories has been a real eye-opener and made me so angry at some of the providers out there).  I'll probably haunt the "just diagnosed" forum a little more but will keep an eye over here and put in comments if I think they'll be helpful.  Sending Light to all...

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 11:38AM Ysa wrote: Kerri, I have no words of wisdom for you as this is also new to me and I've never had mono so have nothing to compare it to.  Just wanted to let you know that the worry and anxiety are very normal.  It's possible that some of the nausea and chest tightening are symptoms of anxiety (that's pretty typical of my symptoms when I'm highly stressed).  You might try contacting one of your doctors to see if they can enlighten you as to the possible cause or prescribe you something for anxiety if that's what they think it is.  There should be on-call docs, or services who can get a message to a doctor. HOWEVER, if the symptoms of nausea and chest tightening get a lot worse and/or you start vomiting from the nausea or having radiating chest pain, consider going to an urgent care (or ER) and have them check you out just to be safe. Sending hugs and Light.  Keep us informed.

Posts.Title: Update Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 10:04PM Ysa wrote: Hi, Sandra.  = ) There is some good stuff posted on the site about tumor characteristics (you may have already found some or all of it) and it will probably help you figure a few things out.  Size is only one characteristic of a tumor.  As you find out more from the biopsy, they will create a profile of your tumor's characteristics.  You already know they will grade it, using a scale of 1 to 3.  Short story is that a grade 1 tumor is much less aggressive than a grade 3 tumor, having to do with how the cells are organized and/or moving around.  Then you'll discover more about things like hormone receptors (estrogen=ER; progesterone=PR) and protein receptors (HER2).  All of these things together begin to form a picture for your doctors as to how you are best treated.  So, short answer is that your tumor size is "small" and that's good.  But until you know the answer to some of the other characteristics determined by the biopsy, no one can really say how likely or unlikely it is to possibly spread nor how quickly.   Having now scared you even more, it is certainly a lot better to have caught a tumor at 8 mm than at over 2 CM...which contributes to an upgrade in overall (eventual) staging.  So, for now, relax in that and your doctor's words of having caught it early because it is still relatively small and worry about all the other crap when and IF it comes along.  And keep going to the info material on this site and places like the American Cancer Society to learn more about how all these tumor characteristics fit together.  If nothing else, the information will provide you with good questions to ask your doctors. BREATHE, know you are surrounded by friends and hugs, and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Ysa wrote: Haven't seen this anywhere but wanted to know if anyone had some insight.  I know that you can see things on an MRI or u/s that don't show up on a mammo but has anyone ever heard of something showing up on mammo that doesn't get picked up on the other two? Had a repeat diagnostic mammogram (original was 12/15/11, which caught my IDC) at MDA on 2/14 and they found another (new) site about 2 CM from my currently diagnosed IDC and appears to be deeper into the tissue.  They were rolling my poor boob all over the place, way beyond my original diagnostic mammo (at one point, I had my whole face plastered to the clear tube that houses the compression plate).  However, they did not see it on the MRI done on 1/23 and couldn't find it on the ultrasound they did later in the day on 2/14.  When I saw my MDA breast surgeon on 2/15, she said that the site newly seen on the mammo was definitely not a shadow and was clearly an actual spot in the tissue.  From the shape, they think it's another malignancy.  Since it would have required a stereostatic biopsy and I am having a BMX anyway, we decided to wait to have it biopsied in surgery. Thanks! Courage doesn't always roar. Sometimes, courage is the quiet voice at the end of the day saying "I will try again tomorrow". (Mary Anne Radmacher); one 9 mm and one 7mm mass in right breast, bone mets/lumbar spine, Xgeva started 12/2012 Dx 1/6/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2012 Femara (letrozole) Dx 11/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 2/19/2013 Bone Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2012 07:05AM Ysa wrote: Deep breath... Never expected to be posting here (and not quite sure if this is the best place so feel free to throw me somewhere else, if not). Had a bone scan on Friday and asked them to send me a copy of the radiologist report as I am not scheduled to see my MO until 11/8. She ordered the scan (and a brain MRI which I am having tomorrow) when I was complaining about persistent back pain and headaches at my August visit. The findings/impressions state, ...Suggestion of upper lumbar spine, probably L1, metastatic focus. MRI evaluation of the lumbar spine recommended... So, I guess the question is what do you think are the odds of the spot being something OTHER than metastases? These are the same radiologists who found my relatively small IDC and every doctor I have seen (including at MDA) thought did an outstanding job of detection, so my level of confidence in their credibility/expertise is quite high. I am not panicking (although I see some xanax nights in my near future) having read these boards enough to know more testing and lots of good years are ahead of me... But I guess I needed to reach out and ask the question during this ACK moment. Thank you so very much and know I have you all in my thoughts, as well.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2012 04:51AM - edited Nov 2, 2012 05:03AM by Ysa Hi, zsterling. Please try not to be scared! There are a lot of unknowns in my family history and if I've learned anything over these last 10 months it is that every dx is unique with lots of personal variables. To your questions: My insurance denied genetic testing when I was first diagnosed and, as it appeared I was a garden-variety early stager, I didn't pursue it due to the cost. I was 55 at dx but, like many of us, was told the cancer had likely been growing for many years before it was large enough to detect via mammography in my relatively dense breasts. I had two spots in my breast and a positive node so, while unlikely to have had it spread, I did realize that it was a possibility. If it turns out to be confirmed mets, I kinda suspect it might have been there all along. I have been on Femara since May 1 and it very well may have already helped! I had no chemo or rads. My mom was diagnosed with BC when she was 59,and has also survived colon and lung cancer. I have never had medical information on my biological father's side so have no idea what may be lingering there. Sending you hugs and hoping you will not stress too much over this. We all are truly unique and the odds really are in your favor right now!

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2013 01:46AM - edited Mar 23, 2013 01:47AM by Ysa Hi, WannaCruiz. First of all, please accept my deep regret that your DD is having to go through this and at such a young age. Having you to turn to must be a real comfort. It sounds as if your DD's medical team is terrific and seeing positive results from the chemo is wonderful. I cannot answer specific questions regarding her IBC or chemo but hopefully someone will come along soon with that expertise. Regarding the reconstruction, it sounds to me that you have not yet consulted with the plastic surgeon? S/he should definitely have an opinion about the timing of the reconstruction and will hopefully consult with her breast surgeon and MO regarding their thoughts on any potential radiation to the breast skin area. Beyond that very important conversation, I would say that anything that makes your DD feel as good about herself as possible is never crazy to consider. With luck, she will be here for a very long time and feeling attractive is a morale boost for anyone. Just make sure to have all the necessary conversations around possible complications with future treatments in mind, and consider her stamina, ability to ward off potential (but hopefully unlikely) infections, and ability to cope with any pain. You might want to read some in the reconstruction threads, as well. If the PS wants to use expanders, there may be some pain issues you will want to be aware of and discuss. Please keep us posted and let your DD know we will be thinking about her and sending hugs to you both.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 10:18PM Ysa wrote: WannaCruiz, it's terrific that your DD's surgery is going to be so soon. While scary, the anxiety waiting for surgery always seemed to be a lot worse than once I was on the other side. As for continuing to bring up the request for no node removable, once it is all agreed upon with the surgeon, may I suggest that it get mentioned to everyone who checks (nurses, anesthesiologist, PAs, and surgeon again) the day OF surgery. My surgical nurse made it clear to me that she had my back in surgery and asked me to reiterate things like the need for strong anti-nausea precautions, etc. The more people who know what the decision is, the less chance for a mistake. You might also ask the surgeon about what her protocol is if she changes her mind during surgery and feels she has to remove any nodes. Just so you're all clear. Sending lots of hugs and Light to you and DD. Keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2013 12:20AM Ysa wrote: jjl...having one or even more positive lymph nodes does not necessarily make you stage IV. To be stage IV/metastatic, the cancer needs to have left your breast area and shown up somewhere else in your body...usually bones, liver, lungs, or brain. Positive nodes could be a signal for your MO to start scanning you for signs of metastases, but it is also possible that your nodes did their job and kept the cancer from spreading further. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 10:52PM Ysa wrote: OMG, Stormy...what a nightmare! Great advice but horrid you had to learn that wisdom at all. WannaCruiz, have them add that, before they do anything not agreed upon, they will come out and discuss it with you. And thoroughly read all the consent forms. I know that in the reconstruction threads, possible changes in the procedure were added by the surgeon if s/he got into surgery and found something unexpected...in many cases, the stated possible change was the very thing the patient had clearly stated she did not want. You might even discuss having your DD give you her medical power of attorney so that there is no question as to your ability to make a decision for her while she is under. I am constantly amazed at the number of huge decisions we have to make so quickly while still trying to process a life altering event of this magnitude. Gah!!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 10:22PM Ysa wrote: Gall bladder is tucked away in there and can radiate higher under the ribs, too. I know that scans can show more than their targeted area, but the radiologist may not be looking beyond that. I had that happen with my abdominal CT scan for my DIEP...at MDA no less. Radiologist was focused on mapping my blood vessels and didn't note the lumbar lesion on my spine (which was visible when my local cancer center ordered it for comparison). Was told that happens often when the scan is specifically for another reason. Sending hugs and hope that it turns out to be something other than what you fear. Hoping you have a great time at your son's birthday.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 03:17PM Ysa wrote: Babs, joint pain is one of the main side effects of Femara/letrozole, which can definitely make figuring out what is causing one's joint pain a challenge! The Femara thread has all sorts of information on it and some of the things folks have tried to ease the pain. I have heard that claritin helps, as well as glucosamine supplements. Definitely mention to your doctor, though. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Need support! recent dx brain mets & meningeal carcinoma Elisha82 sandilee

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 07:23PM Ysa wrote: Hi, seabeal.  I just wanted to connect with you as another New Mexican and let you know you were being hugged by someone nearby.  I was diagnosed in early January and, as my MDA radiologist put it, had to learn years worth of information in just a short time.  I'm actually doing my treatment (surgery and reconstruction) at MD Anderson in Houston.  Love my ABQ BS and the PS I met but the local (NM) health system has gotten in the way of me getting the reconstruction treatment I wanted so off I go (it's in-network for me so that helps). Dragonfly1 said everything just beautifully.  I have had the same experience of having to re-educate (as I was learning) about how being caught early does not necessarily equal safe and secure.  Everyone's disease is a little different and you'll find your way with your doctors as you go.  This is a terrific place to ask questions or just lurk around reading.  Being an RN has got to be a great advantage when it comes to the medical-ese but probably won't help one bit when it comes to the anxiety (I'm a retired social worker who spent many years both in the medical field and as a counselor...didn't help me sleep any better after I was told!!) My husband has been pretty terrific about not saying stupid stuff but had some earlier experience with melanoma (was told it was stage IV but they were wrong....whew) so is a bit more sensitive.  What I am noticing is that my dx affects him very differently and I'm trying to find the balance between my need to spill everything new I learn to him and his need to sometimes talk about something other than my BC.  He doesn't process things like me (geez...lol) and truly just shuts down when he gets overloaded.  We're inching our way through this together, though, and learning better communication skills as we go.  I can't help but feel that sometimes I'm having to take care of him when I'd rather be stomping and crying, but then I remember how I felt when he was dx and try to apply some of the same courtesies.  Be patient and hopefully your husband will turn out to be your biggest support and cheerleader.  Until then (and after), you know we're here for you (and you, too, sandik) to vent, cry, and rage to.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 05:53AM - edited Jan 8, 2012 05:54AM by Ysa Oh, frazzeledmom, I can't believe that you are STILL having to wait for your results.  Waiting over a weekend when you thought you'd have them on Friday just seems so much harder than it should have to be.  Be sure to let us know as soon as you can and know that you have a community sending you lots of hugs. Posts.Title: How did you hear biopsy results--phone or appt? frazzledmom schoolmom

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2013 12:14AM - edited Apr 9, 2013 12:16AM by Ysa My breast surgeon was Dr. Daliah Black and I adored her. If plastic surgery is in your wife's future, Dr. Mark Villa is mine and I also adore him. Even my local radiation oncologist had heard about Dr. Villa's work and thought I was very lucky to have him. I was so NOT impressed with the oncologist they assigned me (she may have been fine technically but had a really terrible way of relating and pretty much blew through my appointment as if I wasn't a challenging enough case for her attention...my sister accompanied me to all my appointments there and felt the same way so I knew it just wasn't me). Fortunately, we have a very good, comprehensive cancer center locally and I get my oncology treatment here. If I were to go back to MDA for onocological issues, I would request a new MO. MDA is huge and very patient oriented so you will be in good hands. They really try to make the most of their out of town patient visits so don't be surprised by rapidly changing schedules to accommodate the testing and doctors they want you to see. You will likely start off with a breast surgeon appointment and go from there. Bring some portable entertainment (I did a lot of reading) and have your wife carry a shawl or sweater as many of the waiting areas and exam rooms can be very chilly. I am sure others will be along shortly with their recommendations. The best of luck and good wishes to you and your wife.

Posts.Title: Brain MRI - Negative :-) JeninMichigan Leah_S

Posts.Content: Ysa wrote: Began to realize yesterday that my anxiety levels were rising and have done the Xanax route (last evening), the self-talk route, the try-to-focus-on-something-else route, and still feeling pretty icky.  It's really kind of stupid and my husband characterized it well when he said that our minds are "GO GO GO" and the world responds with "slow slow slow".  I just feel like my life is on hold right now until I finally get a freakin' return phone call from MDA.  So, thanks for letting me vent and if you have anything you think might be helpful, please feel free to share. After meeting with my local BS in January and a local PS on 2/2, we all decided I would be best served going out of state for surgery.  MD Anderson was highly recommended and, after a variety of phone calls, etc. on Thursday, I found out they were in-network and there should be no problem with me getting my BMX and DIEP.  I called early Thursday afternoon to make an appointment, was told there was an appt. available in a "couple of weeks" and asked if I wanted that one.  I said yes and was told someone would call within 48 business hours.  I was a little iffy regarding the gal who took my name and phone number (she didn't know if they took my insurance but thought they did, didn't give me any specific date for "a couple of weeks", questioned my phone number which has the same prefix--different area code--as theirs, etc.)  Nothing happened on Friday (I was home all day) so, on Saturday, I went ahead and filled out their on-line self-referral form and noted in the comments section that I had called and didn't want them to get a duplicate referral.  Their form asked a TON of questions that I didn't get asked when I first called, so I thought that was good. On Monday morning, I got an email from someone screening my form noting that I had already been assigned a patient access specialist so they were deleting my form.  I emailed back and told them that I hadn't heard from anyone so was just trying to be thorough.  They emailed back and said that they had notes that the PAS had tried to call me on Friday but "couldn't get through".  I was home on Friday, all day.  I have voice mail and call waiting (that goes to voice mail if I don't answer the call waiting).  But maybe someone copied down my number incorrectly. They did at least also provide her name and a phone number to try to reach the PAS.  I turned around and called my PAS (still early Monday morning), got her voice mail, and left a very nice message that I was sorry she had trouble reaching me, repeated my phone number slowly, twice, and let her know that I would be out of the house between 11-1 their time for a doctor's appt. but would otherwise be home.  Her outgoing voice mail did indicate that they return calls by the end of the next business day but I was kind of hoping I'd hear from her yesterday, anyway. Got home from the dr. and had voice mail waiting from someone else but no other calls while I was gone.  And no call by the end of the day, yesterday. I think I'm usually a really nice and considerate person, try to be really patient, get assertive when necessary, but realize we are often dealing with overworked folks, so I've been trying to reconcile myself to waiting but it's getting harder.  To minimize my anxiety, this morning about half an hour after they would have started business hours, I called, got her voice mail again (with the same "return calls by end of next business day" message) and very nicely said I was concerned that she might be having troubles getting through to me so repeated my original (home) number AND gave my cell number and email address, noting I would be home all day. So, it's now 3 hours later and all my best intentions to wait this out and not be a pest are evaporating.  It's probably exacerbated by the fact that I'm waiting on getting this information from them before making several more appts.   I have to travel from Albuquerque to Houston for this first appt., don't know how long I'll need to be there, and want to make sure I'm not double-booking things.  So, I'm on hold.  And it's driving me nuts.  And I think I'm probably being unreasonable and know all the logical reasons this is driving me nuts (and probably shouldn't be), but guess I finally needed to release some of the pent-up anxiety in a safe place. Honestly, in the back of my mind, I'm also thinking about my mom, who finally has her oncologist appt. today to find out what are her next steps for what is likely to be lung cancer (PET scan showed a big hot spot in her lungs--she's already had breast and colon cancer).  My only sister had planned on going to MDA with me and hanging for as long as needed through my time there and recovery at home, but now I'm worried that she's going to start feeling conflicted about whether she should be with my mom or me if things start overlapping.  Okay, so maybe I'll take a small dose of Xanax.  LOL Still, thanks for listening and I'd love to hear your thoughts, especially if you have had any experiences with MDA (good or bad at whatever stage),  Thanks!! Courage doesn't always roar. Sometimes, courage is the quiet voice at the end of the day saying "I will try again tomorrow". (Mary Anne Radmacher); one 9 mm and one 7mm mass in right breast, bone mets/lumbar spine, Xgeva started 12/2012 Dx 1/6/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2012 Femara (letrozole) Dx 11/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 2/19/2013 Bone Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 12:17AM Ysa wrote: Ack.  Thanks for that info, Mom2Tots!  Gonna cross my fingers and hope that all the anxieties I already have about this trip stay in my head and don't become reality!
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 08:20PM - edited Feb 11, 2012 08:27PM by Ysa Thank you both, dreaming and TSB1.  dreaming:  When I did have issues I called the central number, got connected with someone who kindly connected me with the PAS.  From there it was smoother sailing (they had my numbers reversed and the PAS wasn't checking the system number against the messages I was leaving so kept calling the wrong number).  TSB1:  I have a room near the MC which has the free shuttle to/from.  I'm flying into Hobby and already have a super shuttle booked to the hotel but didn't book the return shuttle trip thinking I'd find more out about the area and the metrol rail.  Going in, the super shuttle was all about comfort levels, etc. until I know my way around.  I'm a little agoraphobic and it takes me a bit to get the lay of the land and then I'm good to go.  I'll be back on-line once I get settled at the hotel and you just may get some questions (meanwhile, I'm bringing laptop with movies and the Big Bang Theory seasons for amusement if I get stuck over the weekend for some reason). Thanks, again!!!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 08:03PM - edited Feb 7, 2012 08:04PM by Ysa I will call the UHC cancer resource folks in the morning and ask about that, MiniMacsMom!  Thanks for letting me know.  I had signed in to MyUHC and pulled off my basic coverage information for the reconstruction part but couldn't find a lot of detailed information on handling the cancer itself.  Maybe they can navigate me through that, too. Scuttlers, thank you so much for the info on the bus/rail alternative.  Whenever it is, I had planned on going a day early so should be relaxed enough to navigate that. Come surgery time, my sister and I were hoping to grab a queen room with kitchenette so we were not stuck eating from restaurants all the time, so it's nice to know there are grocery stores within the Rotary's shuttle proximity. Thanks, everyone!
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 08:17PM - edited Feb 7, 2012 08:21PM by Ysa Thought I was going to bed and all possible questions had been exhausted but here is one more (and keep that other info coming.. it's all wonderful)! They want me to bring "Copies of your Advanced Directives including:  Medical Power of Attorney, Living Will, and Out of Hospital Do Not Resuscitate Order. Uhm, does anyone know where I can find templates for these?  The only other times I've had surgery the hospital provided them and I don't have those anymore. Sigh....

Looking forward to hearing how it all goes.

Posts.Title: Why, hello there... Lucys_hair_brained_schemes Lucys_hair_brained_schemes

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 06:58PM - edited Feb 7, 2012 07:02PM by Ysa Thank you ALL!  To catch you up, I did call back at 4:00 their time and got the PAS' voice mail again.  This time, Ieft a message and let her know I was going to call the main number.  I did, got transferred to someone who found my PAS and put her on the line directly.  Turns out that they had transposed two digits when entering my phone number in their system.  The PAS kept calling that number and did finally admit that she had not checked the number I kept leaving on her voice mail against the number in the system, and had called the (incorrect) number several times.  I don't know if anyone owns that incorrect number but I keep imagining their consternation as they get repeated phone calls from a cancer center.  So, the (kinda overwhelming) process is started.  I do have to send out a big kudo to both my local breast surgeon and the imaging center.  When I called them with the ginormous list of reports and notes that they needed to fax to MDA before they would even give me an appointment time, they were all over it and went above and beyond to do it immediately (the imaging center even included an older mammogram from another imaging center from several years ago because they had it for comparison with my "bad" mammogram...no calling around a ton of places to pull it all together).  The imaging center will have my CD of the films ready for me to pick up anytime I want, as well.  And my sweet hubby came home and immediately grabbed my driver's license and insurance card and is scanning and faxing them from his computer right now.  I've also emailed her back and let her know all this should be there already or no later than the morning, and listed the reports she will NOT be getting as none of those tests were ever done.  I suspect we will move along nicely from this point on and it feels so darn good just to have actually done something that moves this forward. On a related note, I was a little stunned at them saying that I should be prepared to stay in Houston for 5-7 business days for the initial consult stuff, not to mention that they routinely re-run the pathology on the original biopsy and it could cost me out of pocket between $250-$2500 if insurance won't cover all or part of it (I refuse to stress that one).  Thank you all, again, for the support and venting allowance.  You made a difference in my coping today and that is priceless (as are you!). Light and hugs...
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 08:27PM - edited Feb 7, 2012 08:31PM by Ysa Thanks, scuttlers (and I'm assuming you mean they have the living will, etc. docs).  I have got to say that this first part of "bring with you everything but the kitchen sink" is a little overwhelming.  If they have the forms there, they should just say you need to fill them out there.  Sheesh!  LOL Edited:  we crossed paths so thanks on that, too MiniMacsMom!  = ) Now, I am REALLY going to bed...full of appreciation for y'all rather than anxiety for a change.  Hugs!

Posts.Title: Why, hello there... Lucys_hair_brained_schemes Lucys_hair_brained_schemes

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 12:13PM Ysa wrote: Thank you, all, for taking a moment to post.  It's nice to not feel alone (and I hate always whining to my hubby and sister...don't want to burn them out.)     = )  Mallory107--my BS here recommended I do a self-referral because it then looks like a request for a second opinion...I think it's an insurance thing and she wants to make sure I get covered compeletely.  I'm not waiting for a specific dr., just the first available appt. and did think they would first put me with a BS and then move me along to PS as we went.  If things go too long, I may ask my local BS to intervene, however.  And I know it's not an emergency (self-talk reality), but it's mostly about me wanting to get my other life-stuff scheduled, too, and having everything on hold.  Thank you, though, for the understanding and suggestions.  barbiecorn--thanks for the advice on the xanax.  I really try to use it when necessary but usually wait until I'm biting my nails.  I've got permission to use it as needed (it's real low dose) so I think I need to follow that advice and not be afraid to take it. I've got a call in for a referral to someone regarding the xanax and a possible anti-depressant, too.  It's nice to see so many women sharing their stories about needing to use those--makes it much easier to consider.  I'm so happy you are post-surgery and hope your drains come out soon!  I'll keep checking on your progress! eulabt--thanks for the wishes and the caring.  Off to clean something.  LOL
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 01:14PM Ysa wrote: Wow, Pegs...that's awful!  My BS office (which is in the middle of MOVING this week) called me today (after just getting the request yesterday when I was there) and have my file copied and are mailing it to me for my (someday?) trip to MDA so I don't have to drive over to them.  However, my PCP doctor's office staff is a little bit like yours.  They even sent me a copy of my bone density scan report postage due (the gal put a really old stamp on it)!!  My husband still thinks I need to tell them they owe me 15 cents!  I think it must really depend on the type of office and experience of the staff.  It's hard to find the right balance of "HEY I HAVE CANCER GIVE ME A BREAK" and the patience of trying to understand what's going on for them.  Have you talked to your doctors directly about the inconvenience and asked for a different solution?  Thanks for caring to post and wishing you smoother sailing, too!
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 07:31PM Ysa wrote: Thanks for the info, MiniMacsMom..after having my first real meltdown last Thursday when I found out that I was going to have to do this out of state, all I seem to have are questions.  My local BS had warned me that they might want to re-do the biopsy pathology...I just hadn't considered the cost.  I also have United HC and they are in-network so I'm hoping it will be covered.  You reassured me a lot on that.  My husband and I started budgeting this all out last week and are so fortunate to have savings that can cover the travel/lodging/other expenses stuff.  It'll put a dent in our retirement but he figures it's a good investment if I'm still alive to handle the vegetable garden we'll probably need to plant.  I plan on taking advantage of their travel service for sure.  What we had already decided was that I was going to try to stay in the Rotary House that connects with and is owned by MDA.  The price is worth it for the convenience (compared against (a) my need to rent a car and (b) the stress of driving in a city I don't anything about).  I will see if there is anything else within walking distance but am hoping to grab a room there, otherwise.  I am an avid reader and have already loaded my Kindle with a bunch of books and my laptop is ready to go.  Being kind of shy and good at amusing myself, waits between appointments won't bother me much.  My sister will be coming to stay with me during the actual surgery/recovery later on, so that will be nice. So, with luck, I'll hear by the end of the week (that's me saying I really hope I'll hear tomorrow or the next) when my appointment is and keep moving forward!  = )
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 08:20PM Ysa wrote: Galsal, they practically forced the Cancer Resource folks on me when I called in to check out in- vs. out- of network providers.  I don't know this for sure but they kept mentioning that it was covered so I assumed all cancer patients got it.  It's basically 6 nurses who can answer virtually any question about coverage, medications/side effects, etc.  I would call the number on the back of your UHC card and ask.  I wasn't sure I appreciated it at first but have come to find them really nice and helpful.. including connecting me with in-network mental health folks I could talk to about this.  Let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 05:07PM - edited Feb 10, 2012 06:11PM by Ysa Just an update for everyone kind enough to help me through.  Got the call this morning that they want me to be there on Tuesday morning for my initial consults.  Got my plane reservations, hotel reservation (boy, Houston is, or will be shortly, fully booked through 3/19 because of their rodeo), and picked up my CD of films.  So more mammograms, ultrasounds, and another possible biopsy scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday morning, then off to see the breast surgeon on Wednesday afternoon.  Since I also want reconstruction, they'll book me with a plastic surgeon once I've seen the breast surgeon on Wednesday, plus a MO if they decide to start me on AI right away (vs. waiting til after surgery). Am going to hope for (and ask for) a surgery date no earlier than at least later in the week of 3/19 so I can actually get a hotel room for my sister (and then the two of us).  Thanks, again, for all the tips and reassurances.  Still anxious but now it's about different things (and more manageable) and I think it's interesting how our anxiety just switches focus as we journey.  Back to lurking.  Light and peaceful healing to all. P.S. TODAY the PAS told me not to worry about bringing all the legal PoA, Living Will stuff with me...without me saying anything.  Hey, couldn't you have put that note on the form where you told me I needed to bring it with me?  Glad y'all were on top of that!  LOL
Posts.Title: Anxiety venting and MD Anderson question Ysa Ysa

Stay focused on your little one's birthday and find what joy there is in something so simple but so special. One step in front of the other... (((hugs))) and (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 10:08AM Ysa wrote: Soleil, so very, very sorry. Sending hugs and prayers that the gemzar will be successful at knocking out those buggers and the nausea is a non-issue.
Posts.Title: Scans Pretty Grim....Sigh soleil505 Cynthia1962

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 06:51PM Ysa wrote: Talk to your folks about helping you find someone who specializes in women's health--especially breasts.  There are some good breast surgeons around (who don't just do surgery but they are usually surgeons, too) who may be able to help you figure out what's wrong.  A general doctor may not understand your fear or concern and, especially because you are very young, may be a little dismissive.  Chances are that it is something very treatable but you shouldn't have to live in pain and fear.  Good luck and send us an update!!
Posts.Title: I just need advice please fabianav geebung

Posts.Content: Ysa wrote: Some specific-to-MD Anderson surgery questions from anyone who can answer.  Thanks in advance! I plan on a BMX with flap (hopefully DIEP) reconstruction immediately, if all goes well.  So far, my local BS and PS feel that should be possible.  The questions come from that perspective. 1.  I have been told (locally) that I may be in the hospital as long as 5 days and then sent back to the hotel for another week or two for recovery and follow-up with MDA.  My local BS and PS both indicated that MDA would probably want me to stay locally for up to 3-5 weeks and it's possible I'd still come home with a drain or two (my local BS will remove any drains).  Did anyone have that kind of experience and can share some insight as to how it went? 2.  Did MDA release you from the hospital with any kind of camisole or compression garments?  Were they good or did you change them for something more comfortable?  I want to know what I might have to have on hand. 3. If I'm going to be recovering in a hotel room that first week out of the hospital, is there somewhere I can get a wedge pillow (either from MDA short-term or rent from someone...or even buy a cheap one locally)? From the DIEP boards, if I don't have access to a decent recliner to sleep in for a few nights, getting in/out of bed and sleeping comfortably appears to be greatly enhanced by having a wedge pillow.  I've got one ordered for at home but can't imagine trying carry it in luggage. 4.  Will the travel service also make arrangments for my sister since she is the one who will be with me during and post-surgery until I can go home?  She needs the same consideration for movable travel dates/no penalties and will be traveling with me on the plane so was curious. 5.  Post surgery travel (or recovering in a hotel) tips? Thanks, again, to all.  I think I finally have the biggest, most burning questions out there and can start to relax a little.  Everyone who helped on the other MDA material was phenomenal!  Courage doesn't always roar. Sometimes, courage is the quiet voice at the end of the day saying "I will try again tomorrow". (Mary Anne Radmacher); one 9 mm and one 7mm mass in right breast, bone mets/lumbar spine, Xgeva started 12/2012 Dx 1/6/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2012 Femara (letrozole) Dx 11/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 2/19/2013 Bone Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 07:56PM Ysa wrote: Kelley33, "bump" is just someone's way of keeping your thread/question active so that other's can see it and, hopefully, give you an answer to your question.  It "bumps" the thread. I don't have a good answer to your question on the seeing vs. feeling other than to give you my experience.  I can feel the fribrous tissue in my breast whereas my tumor and another suspicious area are actually too small (or too deep and small) to feel (not palpable).  They were both found by mammogram and the biopsy on my first tumor was done using ultrasound.  The second area would have had to have a stereostatic biopsy due to its location and size.  Hopefully, someone with good knowledge and experience can give you a more satisfactory answer!  Sending hugs for comfort.
